Posted: December 25, 2016
												Gonna start off by being honest and saying I am 100% a Marvel fanboy. I absolutely love Marvel's movies and comics more than DC. However, I find Batman to be one of the coolest superheroes ever created.But with my Marvel fanboyness in mind... This is one of the best superhero games of all time, far surpassing almost any other that comes to mind. The sheer fluidity of the game, the takedowns, the well crafted story everything just comes together to make one of the best games of all time. Heck, this is one of the few games that actually let's you play your way, for the most part, with stealth or loud as an option. And enemies react based on what you're doing. If you take down all of their friends, they become scared. If they have all of their friends up and standing, they become more confident and taunting. There are so few games that make use of fear as something enemies exeperience, and it works so well for a Batman game.Rocksteady knows how to use Batman's story in the best way possible, and it makes me sad to know there's only one more game after this one. Buy this game at full price, it's worth it.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game is an incredible improvement on the gameplay front compared to Asylum. The freeflow combat system is incredibly fun, and even better than before thanks to new enemy types, new gadgets, and, most importantly, significantly tightened up controls. People who played the previous game will know all those annoying situations when your punch happens to be just a bit too slow to stop an attack, or a counter not working. That happens extremely rarely now - whenever you break your combo, it is your fault. The predator sections are also more fun now, as the enemy henchmen now use their own gadgets to mess up your strategies, like the detective mode-disrupting jammers and mines, which you can also use against them.If you haven't played Asylum, well, prepare for one of the best combat systems in a game, ever. I am not overexaggerating. The freeflow combat system is incredibly simple to leare, but fun and has a lot of depth. It is used in fights with up to 40 unarmed or melee-armed henchmen. It's basics are simple: punch, dodge and counter, but add in the whole different layer of gadgets and special combos, and you really feel like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed Batman. The predator sections are a whole different beast: up to 10 armed henchment in open rooms force you to play stealthily, swinging from vantage point to vantage point to take them out one by one. There are a lot of different ways to do this, from a simple takedown from the back to dragging your enemies over railings, blowing up walls and knocking them out with debris, and my personal favourite, disabling their guns, then dropping right in front of them and watching them struggle helplessly as you pummel them into sleep. There are just so many ways to approach an objective, that I can't help but adore these sections.This game adds a free roaming element to the series, and while it is by no means as developed in full-blown sandboxes, it really ties the game together quite nicely. There are a few sidequests which revolve around you catching various (super)criminals in the titular Arkham City, and they do not feel shoehorned in, although there could certainly be more of them. Simply put, don't buy this game just for the open world, as you will regret it if you do. The riddler trophies and riddles return, and they feel far better thanks to the open world. There is more of them, they give better rewards, and it is easier to find them thanks to the new informant system.As for the story, well, it is really the only weaker side of this game, at least when compared to Asylum. The linear structure of the last game lent itself far better to the type of story Rocksteady was trying to tell, but it is still by no means bad. Still, the big plot twist at the end is far too easy to spot, and the characters feel weaker than they did in the last game.The length of the game is around 8 hours, should you just want to complete the main story. However, 100%ing the game will take far more, which should prove really nice for a completionist like me: Besides the aforementioned riddler trophies and sidequests, there is a new game+ with tougher enemies and combat, but you start with all your gadgets, rather than aquiring them over the course of the plot, a 2-3 hour story DLC, and an incredibly large challenge mode.This challenge mode is a bit hit and miss: some people will find it very repetitive. What you need to know is that it can add around 10-20 hours of entertainment, should you choose to complete it.TL:DR;Chances are, you will really like this game if you liked Arkham Asylum.  If you haven't played it or didn't like Asylum, well, you will probably still like it. All in all, this a really good game and one of my favourite games ever, and I would recommend anyone to try it.

Posted: February 3, 2014
												THIS REVIEW MAY CONTAIN GAMEPLAY SPOILERS!!!I really enjoyed playing Batman:Arkham city, it was one of the best games i've ever played. The fist-fighting is amazing, like when-at various points- you take on about twenty people in one fight. The stealth sequences are also tens, and exciting, after flying across Arkham city beating the small groups of people up, I always liked a good stealth section. The combat consists mainly of spamming x, square, or left-mouse button, and occasionally y, triangle or right-mouse button to counter the thugs' attacks. That sounds incredibly boring, but once you have a high enough free-flow combo(Something that lets you do speacial takedowns and other moves when you have enough punches) you can hurl yourself around the battlefields, not letting anybody attack you because by the time they try you are mangling somebody else, it is very fun. Once you get enough free-flow combo, instead of hurling yourself around like a lunatic, you can also do speacial moves, like one that lets you take out one person automatically. You have to purchase the others when you level up, which takes me to the skill tree. There is multiple things you can invest your skill points on, like the speacial moves in fist fighting, or the different gadgets to use in fist fighting or stealth. The stealth is basically crouch-walking around, not getting detected and stealthily taking people out. Again, this sounds boring, but it is tense, terrifying(especially on one of the stealth boss-battles) and overall, fun. A good thing about it is that if you get detected, for whatever reason, you still have a chance to get away, like there are gargoyles that you can swing around on, and multiple vents and floor grates to hide in, but if the thugs find an unconcious body by one, they will check it, and if you are in it they will start shooting you. The game starts with you as Bruce Wayne, being sent into Arkham city, which is just a walled off section of Gotham city to keep the bad-guys in. You get taken through a section where you are introduced to the combat, and Tyger guards, a group of guards led by Hugo Strange, the mega-bad-guy who knows Bruce Wayne's secrets. You then have to scale a building called Ace chemicals, where you get the batsuit and have to save Catwoman from Two-face. SKIPPING. After a while, you go to Joker's place in a steel mill, where you break into his office, and he poisons you! He knocks you out and-he is poisoned too- He puts his blood in you. You then do a section about Ra's Al Ghul, somebody who controls a Lazarus pit, which is a pit full of danger! You then do a boss-fight against him, which I would say is certainly the best boss-fight in the game. You then get cured and go to wonder tower, which is a big tower in the middle of Arkham city. You do a very difficult stealth bit at the top, where the gargoyles are actually on the outside of the tower so you cannot do inverted takedowns(reaching down off a gargoyle and lifting someone up, strangling them until unconcious, and dropping them with rope attached) You then go into Hugo Strange's office, there is a cutscene, he says "Activate protocol 11" and you run out and the tower blows up and there is a sequence where Ra's Al Ghul kills himself because he will live forever and he doesn't want to.I would definetly give this amazing game 10/10, for its excellence, and I would very highly reccomend it. BUY THIS GAME!!!

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Is it the feeling of being the dark knight? Is it the meaty combat system? Is it the excellent characters and their excellent voice actors? Is it gliding around Arkham City? It's all of these, and it's sublime the way it all glues together.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												Batman: Arkham City is the follow up to the mega-success Batman: Arkham Asylum. It features the same free-flow combat, with even more bat-gadgets for your goon-beating pleasure and a sprawling open city scape for you to grapple and glide your way across. This is also Mark Hamill's final performance as the Joker, Mark having stated the only way he will ever come back to voice Joker is if someone makes an animated version of The Killing Joke comic book arc. In addition to having even more options while playing as Batman, the game also lets you play as other Gotham city heroes Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing, with their own distinct animations and move sets.I need to mention though, that while Batman: Arkham Asylum had typical comic book problems with portrayal of Harle Quinn and Poison Ivy as sex objects, Arkham City offended my wife and I a lot more with the opening sequence. You begin as Catwoman and have to fight a group of thugs while trying to steal something, but unlike the random threats to simply beat and kill the player that Batman receives, Catwoman is treated to her own taunts that include ra pe threats. There is no ra pe in the game as far as I'm aware, but just the suggestion of it really broke my immersion in the game world and made my wife refuse to play it. Batman exists as a very unique property in that he has been portrayed in very dark and gritty ways (Frank Miller's The Dark Knight), but also as extreme camp with jovial and silly aspects (Adam West live TV show). Even if you pretend the live action show never existed, the animated series (which shared voice actors with this game) was still targetted at children and is in the mind of many the iconic and definitive Batman. It just wasn't necessary to include ra pe threats, we already knew these were bad men we were beating up, and dark for the sake of dark is not a good thing. Frank Miller's exploration of the darker side of Batman was also about dealing with getting old, too old to be fighting punks in the street and super-criminals, too old to continue to let Joker get away with with murder sprees. The Dark Knight comics had more to say than just "this is what Batman with even more violence is like".Aside from this (not minor, you play as her more than once) issue with the game, though, the rest is competently executed. The combat is smooth and satisfying, and the difficulty was cranked up a bit since Asylum, especially on the harder settings. There is a LOT of game here for you to discover, with side-objectives such as tracking Zaz by listening to him talk about his origin, and an actual fight with The Riddler if you find all his trophies this time around. I dare say if not for the ra pe threats I would easily recommend this game to anyone, but honestly Batman: Arkham Asylum is all you really need. This game does not offer enough improvement over Asylum to be the definitive game in the series, but if you loved Asylum and want more Batman, Arkham City is mechanically a great game. I do recommend it, because to not do so would be a case of throwing the baby away with the bath water.

Posted: August 5, 2014
												An ambitious folllowup to Arkham Asylum.  Arkham City paints with a much broader brush, but doesn't quite paint a complete picture.  If one were to simply play the main storyline and disregard any sidequests in this game, Arkham City would easily be on par with Arkham Asylum.  However, when the side quests are taken into account, the overall package falls short.  The sidequests feel like constant buildups towards payoffs that don't happen.  Half of the side missions result in nothing more than a nod to past comic book storylines, while the other half culminate in an unsatisfying stealth takedown of the villain who put you through so much frustration to get to him.  When the game asks you to find and collect several hundred collectables only to "reward" you with a stealth gauntlet and a stealth takedown on the perpetrator, it just doesn't feel like you have been rewarded at all.If you were to play this game for fun, I would reccommend ignoring everything but the main storyline.  There's a solid game there, but it is buried in an unfocused and unrewarding open world environment.

												If you enjoyed Arkham Asylum you would enjoy this game.  There seems to be more content in Arkham City over Asylum.  The environment and mood had a slightly scarier feel to it in Asylum, but in Arkham City the open world seems bigger and there are more things to do such as sidequests, more challenge maps etc.  I felt this game went overboard with all the riddles, which actually took quite some time for me, but I would definitely recommend this game.

Posted: December 16, 2014
												Going into this game after playing Asylum, I honestly didn't really know how Arkham City could be better (except the boss fights). But it certainly showed me how- it expands massively on Asylum, building on everything done right in it like a good sequel should. The gameplay is even better, with more gadgets and special moves (even the boss fights were improved, although still not perfect (except the Mr Freeze one; that was just plain awesome!)). I also loved playing as Catwoman. There's also way more content in this, with over 10 side missions, over 400 Riddler trophies to collect, New Game +, Harley Quinn's revenge and all the Challenge maps. With it comes the kinda small, but amazingly detailed open world of Arkham City with tonnes of Easter Eggs to explore. The voice acting is still of film quality and the graphics are awesome. The story may feel a bit jumpy and messy at times, and I didn't think Hugo Strange was that good of a villain (mainly because he has soooooo many opportunities to kill Batman practically gift-wrapped for him and he doesn't take advantage of a single one), but the story was still very enjoyable, particularly the beginning and the ending. Overall, Arkham City is one of the best games I've ever played and is by far the best superhero game ever. 10/10

Posted: January 8, 2014
												Possibly the greatest action adventure game of this (past) generation. That generic genre descriptor really does apply for all the Arkham games though: there’s a lot of action, and you constantly feel like you’re on an adventure. Rocksteady capitalizes on the foundations of Asylum and takes the series along for a ride on the open-world bandwagon; however, they do so in a way that makes their AAA competitors simply look dull and slow. There’s a great feeling of speed and environmental mastery as you use your grapple and cape, upgraded here as a slingshot mechanism that hurls you into the air before bobbing down to maintain lift. Gadgets are now incorporated into your combat repetoire; A-list villains are actually given their due with some impressive boss encounters; the Catwoman chapter is short but immensely fun; environmental puzzles are more complex while the Riddler challenges are compulsively fun to track down and complete. You want to know how to make your collectathon mini games fun? Make them inherently fun, not because they reward a shiny or an achievement or feed your OCD (although all those are legit reasons). 'City' is packed with fun stuff to do.There’s just more of Arkham here: more characters, an expanded moveset, bigger and more diverse environments, more DC universe shoutouts and fanbait (the terrible Harley Quinn DLC is one such tease). It’s the ‘Batman Returns’ of the franchise: a louder and campier sequel that raises the fun quotient significantly, even if it comes at the cost of some narrative and design tightness.

Posted: September 12, 2015
												[PROS]- Play as Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing, each featuring unique play styles and gadgets.- Improved combat engine with more moves and quick gadget commands for Batman and his allies.- Superb voice acting from Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill in addition to notable voice actors such as Tara Strong and Troy Baker.- Variety of Side Missions featuring iconic Batman villains.- Unique boss battles that greatly improve the experiences from the previous installment; Mr. Freeze's battle is especially noteworthy.- 10+ hours of content just for the story mode.- 60 to 80+ hours of content to 100% the game (for completionist players).[CONS]- Riddler trophies can be frustrating to solve and collect.- Completing Catwoman's, Robin's, and Nightwing's Riddler Challenges will take a heavy investment of time and energy;- Each of these characters have limited moves and gadgets compared to Batman which could prove troublesome when earning specific medals.- Expect 40+ hours to fully 100% the game, possibly more if you are not experienced with the predator maps.I recommend Batman: Arkham City to fans of the first game and superhero games in general. Many improvements and the complete access to all the skins and characters, and Harley Quinn's Revenge DLC make this the definitive edition of Arkham City. Great game to buy at a discount (around $5)!

Posted: November 30, 2013
												What can I say that hasn't already been said about this awesome game? You're Batman, Batman! And not only do you play as Batman, but you feel like Batman. Whether leaping from the shadows to takedown your enemies or gliding over the rooftops no other game (besides Arkham Asylum) makes you feel quite like the Caped Crusader.If you liked Arkham Asylum, you're in for a treat. Everything is bigger, and badder. Combat is more intense, and it's a blast to glide through the enormous Arkham City. While Arkham City is a monumental achievement for games of this nature, there are a few caveats. As an open world game, players are given the option to explore and complete side missions at their leisure. While this can be fun, the side missions are repetitive, and largely irrelevant to overall plot. To a completionist, this can grind the story to a halt. I would advise going straight for each main story objective before attempting any secondary missions, as the story is fast-paced and worth experiencing.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												After playing Arkham Asylum, I was thirsty for more. This sequel proved what a sequel should do. Batman Arkham City expanded and improved upon what was already great for a Batman game. A smoother combat and stealth system and additonal tactics for taking out bad guys made this game incredibly replayable. I first bought this game on the Xbox 360, and I just had to to get it again for my PC. This game creates great sub-plots and introduces popular villains that were previously just referenced in Arkham Asylum. The first of the series felt repetitive with a simple combat system of "punch and counter" and fixes it with new enemies and moves that challenge you to utilize new combat moves. The only downsides to this game are the ridiculous amounts of Riddler trophies to collect, and the downplay of certain big-name villains such as Bane. Overall, this is a must-buy.

Posted: January 20, 2013
												The gameplay is top notch. The stealth, but especially the combat, are much improved since the first game. The fluidity of its "easy to learn, hard to master" combat mechanics puts stuff like "Assassin's Creed" (with its silly hold block until you can counter kill simplicity) to shame. In fact, I'm hard pressed to think of another third person game which has better hand to hand combat than "Batman: AC."The open world is a nice touch too, even though alot of the side quests are kind of a pain and best left alone given that they tend to be of the "find x number of hidden objects on a map, then fight a boss" variety. The main plot is better, but never really matches the highs of "Arkham Asylum." It tries to cram every single Batman villain ever into one overarching storyline, and not only does this stretch credulity even in comic book terms, but individual segments feel rushed and lack the depth of "Arkham Asylum" (which focused on relatively fewer villains). Still, if you approach it more as a series of slightly interrelated episodes rather than one grand story the game works much better. Despite its flaws it surpasses the original in most respects and in terms of pure gameplay might be the best third person action game on the market; definitely more polished, better made, and way more fun than any given Assassin's Creed game.

Posted: September 3, 2015
												Words cannot express how good this game is. It is by far, without question, the greatest superhero videogame ever made. Story is amazing and engrossing, side quests are a great way to put in auxiliary villains, and the gameplay is better than ever. Voice acting is at its best in this game, with Kevin Conroy reprising his role as the Dark Knight, and Mark Hamill also returning to voice the Joker. The combat is still as satisfying as ever with each kick and punch smoothly transitioned into the next. Even after completing the story, the challenge maps add hundreds of hours of more content, with 4 characters to choose from (Batman, Nightwing, Robin and Catwoman). Buy the damn game already, you won't regret it.

												After the successful metroidvania style game that was Arkham Asylum, Rocksteady has to really pull something out of the bag for the sequel and Batman: Arkham City does not disappoint.The combat has been tightened up from the previous game and feels meatier and more responsive. Flying around the open world is great, if a little tedious until you get the grapnel gun. Even collecting all of the open world collectibles is satisfying.Even with the slightly lacklustre storyline, made just that much better by the tremendous voice acting and plenty of sidequests to keep you occupied really makes Arkham City into the quintessential superhero game.

Posted: March 23, 2014
												Very rarely do you find a game as flawless as Batman: Arkham City. The aesthetics, the environment, the atmosphere, the characters, the gameplay, the storyline and sidequests, everything blends together to create a purely spectacular fantasy. The Arkham games are Brilliantly crafted, a excellent amalgammation of the more realistic side of Batman that had recently been portrayed in the "Dark Knight Trilogy" and the comic book splendor of fantasy and fiction. Sure, Arkham Asylum was amazing in it's own right, but Arkham City greatly improves upon every aspect of its predecessor, its flaws and its achievements. In all honesty Batman: Arkham City is one of, if not the best depiction of Batman, the Batman world, the villains and storyline in the history of anything Batman, the end result is truly a spectacular and breathtaking game. The storyline and sidequests are sure to keep you interested for hours upon end, the myriad of "riddler trophies" found within the environment are sure to make you think and utilize your wits for success. The features found in the replaying of the game, the "riddler's and harley quinn's revenge, challenges and missions respectively, are sure to also add hours of excitement to the now brimming with bliss container that is Batman: Arkham City. A must have for not merely a Batman fan, but a comic book enthusiast in general.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												***SPOILER FREE REVIEW OF BATMAN ARKHAM CITY***	1/05/15So after spending 17-18 hours with Batman Arkham City and completing the main story, I must say that I am blown away. This game is absolutely unbelievable! The story is so rich and motivates you to keep pushing in the story, the gameplay really makes you feel like Batman, and the amount of things to do in the game is staggering. I still have not completed the Catwomen storyline or any other of the DLC included in the GOTY edition of the game (however, I plan on continuing to play Batman Arkham City so be on the lookout for updated reviews regarding the DLC component of this game). This is strictly a review of the base game of Batman Arkham.Story: 9.5 out of 10	After completing the main story of the game, my jaw dropped. Everything that led up to the end, the struggle, all concluded in an epic finale that I will not forget for a long time. I am not going to discuss the story for fear of spoiling something, but I must say that the story alone is worth the price of admission. The written script is excellent, and Batman is confronted by a numerous amount of famous rivals. Overall, I enjoyed every minute of the story; sequences with the Joker (just like Arkham Asylum) were definitely a highlight in my book.Graphics: 9.5 out of 10The graphics in Batman Arkham City are excellent. The atmosphere is dark, tense, rich with detail, and a feeling of dread overcomes me everytime I play the game (in a good way). However, this does not last long due to the fact that you are Batman! The environments vary greatly in Arkham City. There is a steel mill taken over by the Joker and turned into something resembling a circus act, a police department taken over by Mr. Freeze, a museum occupied by the Penguin, etc. The character models and environment are polished, filled with detail, and provide for a rich Batman experience.- The only thing I disliked about Batman Arkham City is that the game sometimes stutters when gliding over Arkham City which I imagine has to be streaming issue (this is a well known issue among many PC gamers). However, other than this issue, the game runs great on my R9 290. Maxed out, I average about 160+ fps indoors and 90-120 fps outdoors. Do not let the stuttering issue prevent you from playing this masterpiece - you honestly get use to it. A work-around that I use to fix some stuttering issues is to pan the camera 360 degrees around Batman a few times - this really helps!Gameplay: 9.8 out of 10Just like Batman Arkham Asylum, Batman Arkham City is broken into a few gameplay scenarios: stealth, combat, and exploration - Riddler trophies/challenges. Just like the previous game, stealth is one of my favorite parts of this game. As the predator, you hunt down one thug at a time using different tactics such as hanging from gargoyles and performing inverted takedowns, and using a range of different gadgets at your disposal. Overall, the amount of options you have when approaching these scenarios is amazing, and I can totally see myself going back and perfecting my skills in the challenge mode.Combat is much more dynamic and free-flowing than in Arkham Asylum. You can now counter multiple enemies at one time, there are many more enemy types, and there are now more gadgets that are hotkeyed to use to string together combos. The combat in Batman Arkham City can be as in-depth as you want it to be. Overall, the stealth and combat is turned up to eleven as compared to Arkham Asylum, and the game really makes you feel like Batman!The game also comes with 12 side missions (I believe that is right?) that has Batman fighting, tracking down, and helping some classic rivals. Challenge rooms return letting you refine your skills in stealth and combat. Also, with the GOTY edition of the game, Catwomen becomes a playable character whose story becomes intertwined with Batman's. Catwomen controls greatly, her fighting style differs greatly from Batman's, and it is a joy playing as her (I personally prefer playing as Batman, but playing as Catwoman is a nice change of pace.)Lastly, just like Arkham Asylum, Riddler trophies/challenges return in abundance (however this is not a bad thing). Spread out among Arkham City are 440 Riddler trophies/challenges (I have only collected 170). These trophies/challenges really make you scavenge the environment, and provide many more hours of enjoyment to an already fantastic game.Audio: 10 out of 10	It should come as no surprise that the audio in this game is stellar. The voice acting is the best that I have ever heard in a game; the musical score bring out the perfect emotions at the perfect times. Gadgets sound just as they should, and gliding around Arkham City with wind flowing underneath Batman's wingsuit is excellent. I could not wish for anything better in the audio department of this game!Conclusion:	I LOVED BATMAN ARKHAM CITY! It is the reason I love playing video games, and why I continue to do so. This game provides a medium to play as Batman, and should not be passed up on. This game does everything right, and is one of the best games that I have played in the past five years (I do not say that lightly). It improves so much upon the great core provided by Batman Arkham Asylum, yet provides so much innovation to keep the game fresh and rewarding. Do yourself a favor, you owe it to yourself to play Batman Arkham City.Batman Arkham  City		9.7 out of 10BUY THIS GAME!!!!

												Overall Rating: 10.0RPG/Action: AAAIf you have played other Batman games and followed the comics you will agree that Batman returns garbed in a modern, truly intimidating black and grey combat suit. Arkham city provides the ultimate playground to test Wayne Industries latest gadgets with it's distinctive towers, buildings and ruins.You are quickly thrown into the storyline as you first play Catwoman and learn the basics to fighting. You are given freedom to choose when to fight, what side-quests to take up or you could just complete the main storyline while still being able to go back at any time to complete the other stories. Batman AC is a power trip unlocking one gadget which you use both in and out of combat. The controls are very fluid and easy to use. The gadgets you use are very realistic and convincing.If you enjoy a challenge you will not be disappointed. Riddler has left plenty of trophies in difficult locations to get to. But it certainly showed me how- it expands massively on Asylum, building on everything done right in it like a good sequel should. The gameplay is even better, with more gadgets and special moves (even the boss fights were improved, although still not perfect (except the Mr Freeze one; that was just plain awesome!)). I also loved playing as Catwoman. There's also way more content in this, with over 10 side missions, over 400 Riddler trophies to collect, New Game +, Harley Quinn's revenge and all the Challenge maps. With it comes the kinda small, but amazingly detailed open world of Arkham City with tonnes of Easter Eggs to explore. The voice acting is still of film quality and the graphics are awesome. The story may feel a bit jumpy and messy at times, and I didn't think Hugo Strange was that good of a villain (mainly because he has soooooo many opportunities to kill Batman practically gift-wrapped for him and he doesn't take advantage of a single one), but the story was still very enjoyable, particularly the beginning and the ending. Overall, Arkham City is one of the best games I've ever played and is by far the best superhero game ever. 10/10

												What else can I say? The general consensus has already pointed out what everyone would possibly say.However, from a personal standpoint, this game is what defined the superhero gaming for me. TBH, I dont even think there are other companies that can properly compete against Rocksteady's Arkham Series. Asylum was a solid game, a strong beginning to an extremely well polished franchise. City just branched right out, into Arkham City where you are granted the privilege to now free roam.This game has a strong narrative, arguably one of the best I've ever encountered. The gameplay mechanics are fluid and fun, the fights demonstrates batman's actual prowess, maybe 100x more than what Batman movies have ever achieved with their slow, rigid and untrained combat skills. The never ending nights gives this game a darker feel, very atmospheric and immersive as we dive into batmans operations.Overall, the ONLY complaint I have is the lack of a batmobile, which luckily, was introduced in Arkham Knight, the grand finale to this fantastic franchise. Challenge maps are just so fun and have so much replay value, I just go back to it every now and again to just have fun or beat my previous records. Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game is an incredible improvement on the gameplay front compared to Asylum. The freeflow combat system is incredibly fun, and even better than before thanks to new enemy types, new gadgets, and, most importantly, significantly tightened up controls. People who played the previous game will know all those annoying situations when your punch happens to be just a bit too slow to stop an attack, or a counter not working. That happens extremely rarely now - whenever you break your combo, it is your fault. The predator sections are also more fun now, as the enemy henchmen now use their own gadgets to mess up your strategies, like the detective mode-disrupting jammers and mines, which you can also use against them.If you haven't played Asylum, well, prepare for one of the best combat systems in a game, ever. I am not overexaggerating. The freeflow combat system is incredibly simple to leare, but fun and has a lot of depth. It is used in fights with up to 40 unarmed or melee-armed henchmen. It's basics are simple: punch, dodge and counter, but add in the whole different layer of gadgets and special combos, and you really feel like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed Batman. The predator sections are a whole different beast: up to 10 armed henchment in open rooms force you to play stealthily, swinging from vantage point to vantage point to take them out one by one. There are a lot of different ways to do this, from a simple takedown from the back to dragging your enemies over railings, blowing up walls and knocking them out with debris, and my personal favourite, disabling their guns, then dropping right in front of them and watching them struggle helplessly as you pummel them into sleep. There are just so many ways to approach an objective, that I can't help but adore these sections.This game adds a free roaming element to the series, and while it is by no means as developed in full-blown sandboxes, it really ties the game together quite nicely. There are a few sidequests which revolve around you catching various (super)criminals in the titular Arkham City, and they do not feel shoehorned in, although there could certainly be more of them. Simply put, don't buy this game just for the open world, as you will regret it if you do. The riddler trophies and riddles return, and they feel far better thanks to the open world. There is more of them, they give better rewards, and it is easier to find them thanks to the new informant system.As for the story, well, it is really the only weaker side of this game, at least when compared to Asylum. The linear structure of the last game lent itself far better to the type of story Rocksteady was trying to tell, but it is still by no means bad. Still, the big plot twist at the end is far too easy to spot, and the characters feel weaker than they did in the last game.The length of the game is around 8 hours, should you just want to complete the main story. However, 100%ing the game will take far more, which should prove really nice for a completionist like me: Besides the aforementioned riddler trophies and sidequests, there is a new game+ with tougher enemies and combat, but you start with all your gadgets, rather than aquiring them over the course of the plot, a 2-3 hour story DLC, and an incredibly large challenge mode.This challenge mode is a bit hit and miss: some people will find it very repetitive. What you need to know is that it can add around 10-20 hours of entertainment, should you choose to complete it.TL:DR;Chances are, you will really like this game if you liked Arkham Asylum.  If you haven't played it or didn't like Asylum, well, you will probably still like it. All in all, this a really good game and one of my favourite games ever, and I would recommend anyone to try it.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												Batman: Arkham City is just as good as (maybe even better than) the previous title in the Batman: Arkham series! I thoroughly enjoyed every aspect of it. From the gameplay that makes you feel like the Batman himself, to the joy of flying around Arkham City, helping political prisoners from getting beaten up by thugs and finding the Riddler's trophies. If you're a major fan of Batman or just superheroes in general, this is a MUST-BUY for you! It really is just that simple!!Without delving into the game's story and giving away key details, I will just say that the story is nothing short of movie-quality action. Batman is my favourite superhero of them all, and so I couldn't help from getting excited everytime a cutscene would come on, because the voice-acting and character animations are just superb! The music is true to the franchise too and, if you're familiar with the dark world that the latest movies are set in, you will find that this game perfectly represents the world that Batman is set in.One of the best parts of the game is the gameplay itself. Aside from the ability to glide around the city, grappling to gargoyles and rooftops in order to get to places, the combat is what you will be most interested in. Some would argue that it's a simple system of having to attack, counter, attack, counter, and so on. But in the later stages of the game, you will have to learn the movesets of certain enemies that are of a greater risk to you. Facing off multiple enemies with guns, though, will require you to take them out in a stealthy manner. This is where your gear and gadgets come into full play. From the classy batarang to the grenade-like freeze blast, there are plenty of weapons at your disposal to use.So with the game staying true to the Batman franchise, and the gameplay being spot on, the only thing left to discuss are the visuals. Simply put, they are great, and so I have nothing to complain about with them. Even on my 7 year old system (which was close to mid-range at the time) can run this game. And on top of all of this great news, this is the GOTY edition, so you will be able to enjoy things such as Catwoman's storyline, intertwined with Batman's! Definitely get this game, you won't regret it!Enjoy! :D

Posted: January 5, 2015
												***SPOILER FREE REVIEW OF BATMAN ARKHAM CITY***	1/05/15So after spending 17-18 hours with Batman Arkham City and completing the main story, I must say that I am blown away. This game is absolutely unbelievable! The story is so rich and motivates you to keep pushing in the story, the gameplay really makes you feel like Batman, and the amount of things to do in the game is staggering. I still have not completed the Catwomen storyline or any other of the DLC included in the GOTY edition of the game (however, I plan on continuing to play Batman Arkham City so be on the lookout for updated reviews regarding the DLC component of this game). This is strictly a review of the base game of Batman Arkham.Story: 9.5 out of 10	After completing the main story of the game, my jaw dropped. Everything that led up to the end, the struggle, all concluded in an epic finale that I will not forget for a long time. I am not going to discuss the story for fear of spoiling something, but I must say that the story alone is worth the price of admission. The written script is excellent, and Batman is confronted by a numerous amount of famous rivals. Overall, I enjoyed every minute of the story; sequences with the Joker (just like Arkham Asylum) were definitely a highlight in my book.Graphics: 9.5 out of 10The graphics in Batman Arkham City are excellent. The atmosphere is dark, tense, rich with detail, and a feeling of dread overcomes me everytime I play the game (in a good way). However, this does not last long due to the fact that you are Batman! The environments vary greatly in Arkham City. There is a steel mill taken over by the Joker and turned into something resembling a circus act, a police department taken over by Mr. Freeze, a museum occupied by the Penguin, etc. The character models and environment are polished, filled with detail, and provide for a rich Batman experience.- The only thing I disliked about Batman Arkham City is that the game sometimes stutters when gliding over Arkham City which I imagine has to be streaming issue (this is a well known issue among many PC gamers). However, other than this issue, the game runs great on my R9 290. Maxed out, I average about 160+ fps indoors and 90-120 fps outdoors. Do not let the stuttering issue prevent you from playing this masterpiece - you honestly get use to it. A work-around that I use to fix some stuttering issues is to pan the camera 360 degrees around Batman a few times - this really helps!Gameplay: 9.8 out of 10Just like Batman Arkham Asylum, Batman Arkham City is broken into a few gameplay scenarios: stealth, combat, and exploration - Riddler trophies/challenges. Just like the previous game, stealth is one of my favorite parts of this game. As the predator, you hunt down one thug at a time using different tactics such as hanging from gargoyles and performing inverted takedowns, and using a range of different gadgets at your disposal. Overall, the amount of options you have when approaching these scenarios is amazing, and I can totally see myself going back and perfecting my skills in the challenge mode.Combat is much more dynamic and free-flowing than in Arkham Asylum. You can now counter multiple enemies at one time, there are many more enemy types, and there are now more gadgets that are hotkeyed to use to string together combos. The combat in Batman Arkham City can be as in-depth as you want it to be. Overall, the stealth and combat is turned up to eleven as compared to Arkham Asylum, and the game really makes you feel like Batman!The game also comes with 12 side missions (I believe that is right?) that has Batman fighting, tracking down, and helping some classic rivals. Challenge rooms return letting you refine your skills in stealth and combat. Also, with the GOTY edition of the game, Catwomen becomes a playable character whose story becomes intertwined with Batman's. Catwomen controls greatly, her fighting style differs greatly from Batman's, and it is a joy playing as her (I personally prefer playing as Batman, but playing as Catwoman is a nice change of pace.)Lastly, just like Arkham Asylum, Riddler trophies/challenges return in abundance (however this is not a bad thing). Spread out among Arkham City are 440 Riddler trophies/challenges (I have only collected 170). These trophies/challenges really make you scavenge the environment, and provide many more hours of enjoyment to an already fantastic game.Audio: 10 out of 10	It should come as no surprise that the audio in this game is stellar. The voice acting is the best that I have ever heard in a game; the musical score bring out the perfect emotions at the perfect times. Gadgets sound just as they should, and gliding around Arkham City with wind flowing underneath Batman's wingsuit is excellent. I could not wish for anything better in the audio department of this game!Conclusion:	I LOVED BATMAN ARKHAM CITY! It is the reason I love playing video games, and why I continue to do so. This game provides a medium to play as Batman, and should not be passed up on. This game does everything right, and is one of the best games that I have played in the past five years (I do not say that lightly). It improves so much upon the great core provided by Batman Arkham Asylum, yet provides so much innovation to keep the game fresh and rewarding. Do yourself a favor, you owe it to yourself to play Batman Arkham City.Batman Arkham  City		9.7 out of 10BUY THIS GAME!!!!

Posted: August 20, 2016
												The second installment of the Arkham series, Arkham City, does not disappoint. Arkham City brings back, and vastly improves upon, the "free flow" combat of Arkham Asylum with even more gadgets to add to your repertoire. Arkham City is just that a city, no longer are you confined to the walls of Arkham Asylum. Mark Hamill reprises the role of the Joker, he again kills the role as one would expect. In addition to the Joker a plethora of villains from Ra's al Ghul to the Mad Hatter to familiar faces, from Arkham Asylum, such as Harley Quinn and Poison Ivy make Arkham City their home. The main story is every bit as good as Arkham Asylum, with some of the side stories being a little lack luster almost forced so that some of the smaller villains could make an appearance. All in all Arkham City is a must play.

												[9/10] – Quite possibly the best super hero game I’ve ever played, and for very good reasons. This title (as well as the prequel) is a masterfully crafted piece of art. It’s dark, mature and even scary at times. It is the exact incarnation of awesome that I always wanted out of this genre of game. If you ever thought for a second that you wouldn’t play this because it’s a super hero game, then I invite you to contemplate how much♥♥♥♥♥kicking, batarang throwing boss’ism you are missing. It’s very well-paced, with fantastic voice acting, an incredibly detailed and interesting environment. There are loads to explore and do, including awesome side quests and upgrades to collect, each as rewarding as the last. It also has a deceptively intriguing story coupled with one of the best combat systems I’ve seen a very long time. You are quite literally the awesome that Batman is when you play, and quite literally missing the ♥♥♥♥ out if you’re not.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												This game allows you to absolutely feel as though you are the Dark Knight, soaring over the streets of Gotham as you dispense punches and beautifully choreographed arm bars. The graphics are lush and full of detail, and the city center turned prison complex is fully realized, with mutiple environments staged throughout Arkham City. The main part of the game involves you flitting about a decaying and dangerous skyline, but sections of the game will take you into abandoned subway tunnels, inside decrepit police departments, and trudging through the forgotten ruins of turn of the century Gotham City. The story is servicable, though rather forgettable, considering how many times your objective radically shifts from one villian to another. It has incredible moments however, that allow it to transcend this possible fault, in that those moments are where you can simply bask in the joy of BEING Batman, on one of the worst nights in his long career. All of it, taken together, story, combat, control, and the environment, means that Batman: Arkham City, is arguably the best comic book inspired game ever made, and it is undoubtedly one of the finest games of this fading generation.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												     Wow, it's great and I really recommend it.The fighting mechanics are very well done and it really feels good to punch baddies to the face. Also the fact that many of the gadgets are usable in many types of situations (ie. Fights, Puzzle solving) creates a nice feel of variety to the game.     This game reminded me a bit of Sly 3 on PS2, because you can fly above a city that you are free to explore. The world is        Just a lot bigger in Arkham City. Also more mature and dark. I really like the atmosphere there.     Then there's the characters. Oh man, they're so well created. I specially liked the Joker and Harley Quinn. I'm not a big Batman fan, I have seen at least one Batman movie, but I don't really remember what any of the characters sounded like in them. Still I really, really liked their voices. In fact I liked them so much, I would play the game again just for that.     Speaking about playing the game again, there's this great thing in this game called "New game plus" which let's you start the game all over again, with tougher enemies. To keep the balance though, you can keep all your gadgets and upgrades from the first playthrough.     Overall, I think this was a great buy and you'll probably like it if you liked Sly (Especially Sly 3) when you were younger, or just generally enjoy the action/adventure genre.

Posted: March 1, 2013
												First off, if you've not played Batman: Arkham Asylum yet then you shouldn't touch City as City is a direct sequel, plus Asylum is an amazing game in its own right.Now I'm going to assume you've beaten Asylum  so that I can talk at length about City because this game not only lives up to the really high standard Asylum set, it surpasses it in every way.The main difference between Asylum and City is its pacing and game world. While Asylum had a very direct, linear path due to its constricted size, City throws all of that out of the window giving you a huge open world complete with various sidequests, ranging from AR training sequences to practice your gliding skills to you unearthing many villain's plots, ultimately finding them and incarcerating them, and last but definitely not least, the Riddler trophies and riddles, which make a comeback in an even grander scale.The story didn't lose any quality, the voice acting and overall feel of the game are as top notch as before, the combat has been further improved, with things such as multiple counters, and Batman can use several more gadgets than the previous game. However, Batman is not the only character you can play this time. Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing are all playable characters, the latter unfortunately not being in any story related content, only present in the Riddler's challenges mode. Every single one of these characters plays quite differently to the Dark Knight, and all have their strengths and weaknesses. So while you will have to replay challenges four times, one for each character, it'll feel fresh thanks to their different abilities.Now that it has had its DRM removed, there's nothing stopping you from playing this game.

Posted: March 20, 2016
												Batman: Arkham City is a third person action adventure game developed by Rocksteady Studios in association with Warner Bros Interactive Entertainment on the Unreal Engine. It follows billionaire playboy Bruce Wayne AKA Batman after getting arrested and admitted to a city sized insane asylum dubbed "Arkham City" by an enigmatic scientist, and has to fight his way out whilst simultaneously hunting for a cure to a mysterious TITAN side-effect that threatens to infect all of Gotham.Much like the first Batman: Arkham game, Rocksteady has managed to create a player-narrative experience that feels just as grand and exciting as it was in the first game, but this time the gameplay has been properly honed and the direction now turns toward a GTA-esque city dynamic with side-missions as well as story missions.And as sequels are Rocksteady has addressed the complaints given and now I'm here to report the state of all the problems I listed in my review of Arkham Asylum, to see if they're really up to snuff and to see if this game is worth it.Let's a go!Batman's Detective Vision has been downgraded in a few ways, now it's more difficult to tell which directions enemies are facing, as well as a much murkier style that encourages the player to switch between normal vision AND detective mode. The keyboard and graphical settings are still on a different program, and now you have to specifically look for it it doesn't open on start up like before. Killer Croc does show up in this game but as a cameo so I can't really comment on it, that being said most set-pieces are well placed and exciting unlike Killer Croc's overly slow and unchallenging game of red light green light. The opening of this game gives you almost all the weapons you had originally, which is exactly right for the games pacing.The setting of this game is still atmospheric but now has a lot more character, and feels lively. The final boss with Clayface is still a little bit underwhelming but it's fun and epic and leads to the conclusion that really sells the rest of the game so I'll give it a few points for that alone, and the other bosses are also incredibly fun and much better than the first game's, requiring strategy and variety (Highlights include Ra's al Ghul and Mr Freeze.) The combat is just as solid but now it's made a little easier to perform combos and the countering system is more responsive, but there's still not auto run. The disposal of Harley Quinn in this game isn't really a factor but a similar issue arises with The Penguin who's there from the very beginning but has what seems like frankly boring final encounter before pulling the rug from under you with a surprise boss fight that is anything BUT underwhelming. The attacks from Harvey Dent similarly have nothing to do with the plot and also kind of halt progression, and if you're playing as catwomen the exact same problem is there again with Poison Ivy. The story structure is yet again somewhat repetitive but this time it just works better for whatever reason, and the stealthing is much more varied with smarter enemies who will go so far as to pay special attention to gargoyles if they see you flee to one.The logic involving Riddles is more interesting and makes me really think about my surroundings. The riddler trophies do this really interesting thing where you see a lot of them before you have the tools to get them which makes finding them more gratifying, and sometimes when you DO get them you feel like a freaking genius the first time I figured out a puzzle using the remote control batarang and conducting electricity with it I was singing my praises higher than an egotistical ballad singer.The detecive vision is darker and murkier making key things stand out more, and the normal vision world around you is vibrant and interesting to look at no matter what you're doing. The maps inside buildings are at better scale with the buildings outside them, and overall this is one of them best sequels I've ever played.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												Oh Batman: Arkham City, how I love thee.  I don't even know where to begin to explain how fantastic this game is.The story in itself is good, but where the game really shines is in worldbuilding.  The titular Arkham City is probably one of my favorite locations in all of gaming.  The art style and level design just brings the superprison to life, and even the simple conversations between inmates that you can eavesdrop on make the game incredibly immersive.  That's to say nothing of the excellent use of Batman's villian cast.  To go into too much detail would spoil many sidequests, but suffice to say that all are expertly designed, in character, and brought to life by their respective voice actors/actresses (the Riddler being my personal favorite).As for gameplay, it's just as excellent as it was in Aslyum, but has been improved upon like a good sequel should.  On the combat side, you now have the ability to counter multiple enemies at once, all gadgets can be easily incorporated into combat, new special takedowns, and the animations are just as well-detailed from each punch to counter to special takedown that give the combat a finese that few games can match.  And of course, we have the inclusion of multiple playable characters this time as well, from Catwoman to Robin to Nightwing, all of whom have their own unique gadgets and takedowns that shake up the combat.  Stealth as well gets some minor improvements (the ability to quickly end silent takedowns a very welcome addition), and the new gadgets available also offer new ways to neutralize enemies.  Some now take place outdoors as well, giving you even more verticality to the encounters and more tactical approaches and considerations.And of course, we have the challenge mode carried along from Aslyum.  There are now twelve individual maps (split evenly between combat and predator missions), and a new addition: campaign modes, where you tackle three maps back-to-back with qualifers chosen by the player that can either handicap or give you a helping hand.  Unfortunately, this is where I have one big criticism for the game, as the predator missions erroneously followed in the tradition of Aslyum by requiring you to complete specific objectives to beat a level.  On top of most of these objectives being completely arbitrary, and even pointless, then just restrict the player's opportunity to experiment and serve only to make the maps repetitous.  It's a shame they went this route, because the predator encounters in the story mode are fun precisely because they don't have such arbitrary requirements.  Thankfully, the combat challenges aren't structured this way, allowing you to actually experiment with the many combat moves and not be rigidly locked into a routine, and are genuinely fun, meaning you'll want to go back and play them many times over.Tl;dr Batman: Arkham City is easily one of the best games I've played in years, and I could not recommend it highly enough.

												   This is a sequel done right. The previous game had masterfull level design and a lot of highs but, a weak story in my opinion and one of the worst ending bosses and scenarios in gaming history. This sequel checks all the boxes to deliver what I believe is still the best Batman game of all time.    Its bigger and more thought out. Not only is the story great but it has twists and turns as is goes on. It's a story within a bigger plot within a BIGGER one. Quite well executed and an improvement from the original. Another positive feet are the side-mission. They are not over saturated and they appear rather organically as you traverse through the large sandbox.Combat has also been improved, giving you more options to proceed with your combos, new moves and animations chage the feel of the game compared to Asylum.    I really have nothing bad to say about the game, perhaps some boring repetetive missions and random ocurrences but I really don't mind. This was a testament that the first game was not merely and experiment. This game, a Batman game influenced many games to come in modern game history. Say what you want, everything is subjective but in my eyes, This is one of the best games ever made.

Posted: March 14, 2016
												Absolutely fantastic design and gameplay, great addition to the open world and superhero genres.Batman: Arkham City is, as the title suggests, a Batman game with an open Arkham City to explore at your pleasure. Movement feels very fluid as you traverse the monotonously dark city, not saying that's a bad thing. In fact, that's one of the reasons the theme bleeds through so well; the entirety of the game revolves around the gloomy landscape in every one of the missions I've played, main story or side quest. Arkham city is full of lies and crime, and the scenery reflects it.One of the main selling points of the game is the combat. It's simplistic, but still manages to be extremely satisfying and gets quite deep with combos and take downs that you can utilize in different scenarios. The game even incorporates the gliding mechanic into combat, allowing you to swoop down on an enemy and with upgrades, take down multiple at once. Hand to hand feels extremely fluid, almost all counters feel incredibly natural from any angle. Very impressed with just how satisfying combat feels despite only requiring a couple buttons. You can also use your gadgets to disarm and disorient, adding a level of stealth to the game.Speaking of stealth, some missions require you to sneak through passageways and use "detective sense" to figure out  different puzzles. Some gadgets and combat mechanics support this, such as smoke bombs to hide you from enemy vision and silent takedowns to avoid being heard by other enemies. Though it doesn't play a major role in terms of free roaming, it is important in missions and is crucial to master in order to advance to later levels of the game.The last thing I'm going to talk about is completion. In a lot of open world games (i.e. the Assassin's Creed series), there are usually points in the map where you can "activate" in some way to just have some more completion of the game. In Arkham City, these points come in the form of Riddler Trophies, where they require you to solve various puzzles in order to claim them; from everything to simon-says-like memorization to sliding under a grill at the right time. You can spend as much or as little time as you want on these, they're just another thing that you can do that really increases the replyability of this game.Anyway, this game is absolutely amazing so far, I can expect to have a lot of fun with it in the future.
