Posted: March 24, 2016
TL;DR Just buy this game already, it is a masterpiece !This is certainly one of the best games I have played recently, it has everything one could ask for a batman related game !Now, don't get me wrong, honestly I'm not a huge comics fan myself so I wasn't even expecting much out of this game, and  I genuinely had never heard of any of the batman's adventures before so I first played this game literally without knowing anything about him, his allies and his enemies.Well, it turned out to be a great game !The plot is simple yet quite fascinating; you play as the batman, whose real identity is Bruce Wayne, and you're standing against this new "Arkham City", a.k.a a giant prison built in the very heart of Gotham City which is ruled by Dr. Hugo Strange.I'm not going to spoil much of the plot itself, because it is really a good one and I don't want to spoil the fun in exploring it, but know that almost every single batman villain (or at least every villain I know eh) will be present, including the known Joker.The gameplay is pretty good itself, you'll be given many gadgets to solve numerous puzzles with, and you'll be able to fly across the locations of the game with your batman suit. Perhaps the only bad thing gameplay-wise is the combat system, which can be a little easy once you understand how it works, but it is a solid experience regardless.I don't know how much time other people took to finish this game, but it took me 10 hours to finish it at normal difficulty without even touching one single side mission; in fact, I have only just scratched the surface of this game's contents, because, as you continue your adventure throughout the game, you'll unlock challenge maps named which can be played at a latter date, and you'll also unlock a new gamemode upon finishing the game, which will allow you to play the game again but at a very higher difficulty.A lot of years have passed since the official release of this game and yet it still feels fresh, definitely a must have in your steam library.9/10

Posted: April 5, 2016
												I've been trying to think recently of a franchise that told a complete story in two installments; you see trilogies and standalone things all over the place, as well as quadrilogies or whatever they're called, but having 2 installments falls right into the uncanny valley between having one and three (Rule of Three is great and all, but you see it ALL THE F*CKING TIME). Anyway, I think the Arkham games have done that. I don't mean that there are only two installments, as that's demonstrably untrue, but Arkhams Asylum and City form a complete story all by themselves, with no further elaboration required. I like that a lot.Anyway, you want to know if the game's good. Yes, but not quite as good as its predecessor (perhaps my sequel bias again). Overall, this can be attributed to a lack of focus, and seeing as this is a sandbox and Asylum was fairly linear (albeit with a lot of backtracking) that's not at all surprising. However, I'm going to break down the game's elements one by one and discuss them separately.The story suffers from one of the laziest faults in storywriting everywhere: no clear structure. Stuff happens, and then stuff keeps happening, and eventually stuff stops happening as all the various story threads tie themselves up in a nice little bow (mostly). Anyway, it's functional, the setup gives a good sense of escalation from the previous game (which is where I got the 2-installment thing from), and the ending is quite good, so I'll say the story is alright.The combat has been added to without increasing the number of basic elements, which is a really nice thing. There are new animations and context-sensitive takedowns and types of enemies and weapons, so now Batman can do even MORE questionably-nonlethal things to people who probably don't deserve it. However, the way some actual new moves are introduced is a bugbear for me, which I will discuss below.The upgrade system makes no sense, at least in part. Arkham Asylum had the same issue, so I'll talk about both games as one. Batman getting new equipment at predetermined points is fine, because it wouldn't make sense to bring your Line Launcher or Super Duper Upgraded Batclaw wherever you go; you'd call it in or otherwise recieve it as the situation demanded. That's great. I'll even accept upgrades to current equipment, as that still has a veneer of plausibility. But learning new moves over time is just stupid. It's established that the Batman here has been doing this a while, so he's already as good as he's going to get. Why on earth would he, after beating up a certain number of dudes, decide that now he can hold and throw two Batarangs at once, or walk on a tightrope? It's even worse with Arkham City, as firstly the little upgrade bar is called XP, suggesting that Batman had a massive stroke between games and needs to relearn everything; and secondly, the upgrades are presented and unlocked in a grid that reveals more upgrades over time in a pattern that is in no way intuitive. Ugh.Also, there are Catwoman levels, which are fine. Thief Vision irritates both my eyes and the part of my brain devoted to spotting contrivance, but otherwise it works well, and Catwoman is a fun character here.There's a sandbox now, which is fun to get around but I never utilized the side-missions element of. I would appreciate a game in which it's just a normal night and Batman swings around Gotham with all of his stuff, beating up the occasional hoodlum.The boss fights and character animations are better.Overall, Arkham City is a good game, and worth playing. It's not quite as good as Arkham Asylum, in my opinion, but that's no reason to not enjoy it for what it is. Buy it, play through it, and maybe go after all the additional postgame content if you're really having fun with the gameplay.P.S. THEY DID THAT THING WHERE THEY CHANGED AROUND ALL THE HOTKEYS FROM THE FIRST ONE, SO YOU ALWAYS GET CONFUSED AND SELECT THE WRONG THING

Posted: May 28, 2016
												This is great game you should buy it.Pros:-Gameplay is great and fun it only has 2 button combat but it is challenging and i prefer to play the new game + because it gets rid of the icons about enemy actions so you need to keep eye on all the enemies yourself.-Great voice acting-Characters are well done-Good graphics/ art style they still hold up very well even in 2016-playing as Catwoman is fun, it brings fresh variety to game so you can switch character if it gets boring (you can play as both after beating the story)Cons:-Obvious remnant from the console port/ lack of effort for the pc version are the low resolution blurry pre-rendered cutscenes that shouldn't be in a pc game. This also makes the optional Batman skins mostly useless since the cutscenes just show the original outfit because they aren't realtime cutscenes like they should be.-Catwoman's missions should have been longer (They were the most fun missions in the game, at least for me)-No missions replay option. You could replay Catwoman missions in console version but they decided to remove that from the pc version for some strange reason. There is a way to replay missions on pc version but you have to manually make a backup of the savegame file before each mission you wish to replay and then overwrite the nomal save file with the backup file when you wish to replay (Steam save cloud must be disabled)-The DX11 mode is badly optimized and has bad fps drops and stuttering, using DX9 mode works alright.Overall great game, my complaints are very small compared to how much fun the game is.

Posted: February 7, 2016
												Arkham City was a wonderful sequel to Arkham Asylum, not only story wise, but with litterally taking everyhting great about asylum and multiplying it by 20. Here we have a much bigger map to explore as well as lots of interesting characters and side quests. Playing through all the side quests doesn't feel like a hassle and in fact I found my self excited to play through them, they all features characters that i personally loved and they were lots of fun. The twists and turns of the story line in Arkham City will keep you hooked from the beginning and you wont want to stop playing until you finally reach the end and learn everything about Protocol 10 and The Joker. This game is a thrill ride from start to finish and should be a pick up if you're a fan of Batman or just looking for a decently sized action game. This game (for my system) had never dropped below its 62 fps cap and ran buttery smooth the whole way through expect for one crash I received at the end of the Harley Quinn DLC but booted back up and finished no problem. Side note: When doing the Mysterious Figure side quest, Azrael may not show up a the location he is supposed to, meaning sometimes he just wont be there, a fix is to simply exit the game back to the main menu and continue your story and he will be there. (figured I'd mention this as I was confused when it happened to me).

Posted: February 18, 2016
												This is the best game I've played in years and I believe a worthy successor to Arkham Asylum.I felt Asylum streamlined you a bit while City let's you do your own thing. Unlike the Elder Scrolls game though, I want to complete the main story line.Story/Writing:I loved the writing. I thought they kept true to the characters (small issue with Ra's). I loved how the little extra stuff you do unlocks bio's and tapes (like in the first game) that flush out the writing. The main story line is  good, not great, but good and the characters really do carry it.Gameplay:Flying around as the batman is such a satisfying feeling. I prefer predator mode (stealth) over the punch your way through, but they both feel really good to do. I enjoy the different gadgets and being able to use them in combat. I liked that i didn't need to complete everything in the game and could still play through. I enjoy the lvl up system (which is just upgrades).Bugs: I experienced one bug in which the map showed a mission location that had already been completed. That's it. No crashes, no characters phasing into walls. Nothing else in 50 hours of play.I'm just going to say this game improved the series and is one of the best games i've ever played. (10/10)

Posted: March 12, 2016
												A journalist once discribed Batman-Arkham Asylum as a love letter to the Batman franchise; and Batman Arkham City hands you a game that follows that exact MO. Unlike the portrayals of characters and events in the film industry, this game (as with Arkham Asylum) delivers you characters with motives and emotions true to the roots. It certainly isn't beating Superman down. An excellent example here is the sections with Mr Freeze, who isn't the moron that Arnie played, but a sad, desperate man willing to do anything and try any angle to save Nora. No spoilers, but you understand and relate to his actions and you unwittingly feel sorry for him and his fate.The game in itself is excellent, with an amazing cast of script writers, voice actors and level designers. It really gives you the feeling of being the Dark Knight himself.The only minor negative point I have is the collection system with the Riddler trophies. Although mostly brilliantly presented, it ends up becoming a grind with way too a large quantity, and with some trophies not making sense at all. Example: Why would Riddler want you to use a certain weapon a certain amount of time? How would he know and why would he care? Why should I?Regardless. Even as someone that does not nessesarily care for the franchise, this game is highly recommended as with Arkham Asylum. Get it now.

Posted: March 18, 2016
												Batman Arkham Asylum was a real surprise to me. I enjoyed every bit of it. However, when Batman Arkham City was released, I got I little bit confused with all the new things. After all these years I decided to give this game another chance and bought it on sale.  Here is my _personal_ list of pros and cons: Pros:- Very engaging world. Especially the radio transmissions- Beautiful graphics. The world design is very authentic - this is exactly how I picture Gotham city- Gameplay is very polished. This includes combat, stealth and movements- You can play Batman, Catwoman and even Robin- The Wonder city below :)Cons:- Well... the open world. Besides the stunning views, the ability to glide through the city and dramatically sit on gargoyles, the open world annoys me. This is the first thing that I disliked in comparison to Arkham Asylum. Also, the collectables- Characters.  I just don't dig into seductive Catwoman, Batman's problem with killing and other stuff. Well, I have never read any Batman comics, so I had hard time to enjoy this. But I watched two Burton's movies, the unspeakable third one and all Nolan's movies. I liked the atmosphere of the Gotham city in Burton's movies. But the characters are the best in Nolan's.

Posted: March 21, 2016
												Arkham Asylum had only one major flaw – the game was so painstakingly, overwhelmingly, wonderfully thorough in its depiction of the Batman universe, we couldn’t imagine what was left to cover or accomplish in a sequel. The developers at Rocksteady got every element of the character right, from his combat to his gadgets to his previously neglected detective skills. They featured half a dozen of Gotham’s greatest villains, then included hidden references to nearly 30 more just as fan service. They created a setting with enough macabre detail to capture the comics’ horror, but with enough epic scope to somehow fit a Batcave, Batmobile and Batwing.This was it. This was the perfect Batman game.Yet from the moment we started Arkham City, all we could think was: Arkham Asylum was practice. Compared to its sequel, the “best superhero game ever” and our choice for Game of the Year 2009 seems like a tech demo, a first draft, merely a blueprint for what the perfect Batman game can actually be. This is it.For an immediate idea of how much bigger and better Arkham City is than its already incredible predecessor, take a look at this list of the Batman villains mentioned in Arkham Asylum, but never seen. Half of those now play major roles in the sequel, in addition to return appearances by all except one of the rogue’s gallery introduced in the original. Throw in new heroes like Robin, Alfred, Vicki Vale and Talia al Ghul, as well as a bunch of surprise cameos we wouldn’t dare spoil here, and you have a cast numbering in the “holy cow, did Joel Schumacher direct this?!” range. That fear is unnecessary, however, because the game’s writers and developers have succeeded in fully developing and fully justifying every character’s place in a narrative that makes complete logical and dramatic sense. It’s really rather miraculous.Seriously, this story is special, combining the humanity of the best Animated Series episodes, the brutal darkness of a Frank Miller comic and the confident risk-taking of a Christopher Nolan film. There are no moments as subversive as the fourth-wall break in Arkham Asylum, but there are countless moments of awe, shock and squealing fanboy glee – hell, you’ll be overpowered by all of those emotions within the first 15 minutes of the game alone. By the last 15 minutes, you may honestly choke back some tears, and not for a reason you’d ever predict or ever expect a superhero game to deliver.Of course, the most obvious upgrade in Arkham City is, well, Arkham City. At the time the original game released, a small island asylum seemed like the only possible setting for a properly done Batman experience – attempt to render the sprawling streets and skyscrapers of Gotham itself and you’d sacrifice BioShock-level detail for GTA-style size, and might as well be developing a Superman or Spider-Man game. The sequel, though, proves that assumption wrong. The asylum remains on an island of sorts – a bordered, quarantined section of Gotham City – but is at least four to five times as large as before, and if anything, more detailed.Stand still at any point and the magnitude of both Arkham City’s epic scale and atmospheric intricacy will floor you. Endless rooftops stretching into the horizon, each with a different neon sign (Ace Chemicals, where Joker was born) or peeling billboard (“The Terror”, Clayface’s famous movie role) or deadly booby trap (left by the Riddler, no doubt). An apartment building that can be instantly recognized, not only because Selina Kyle’s cats are outside one of the windows, but because every building in the environment is unique. A gigantic carnival Ferris wheel that, when scanned with Detective mode, reveals a hidden body in each compartment. Snow falling as helicopter spotlights crisscross through the night sky and fire burns in the distant background, leftover from a battle that – at some point in the game – you fought.Who are we kidding? You won’t stand still. While Rocksteady hasn’t given players the keys to the Batmobile yet, gliding and leaping and diving and climbing and rappelling across this expansive playground with the use of Batman’s cape and tools offers just as much exhilarating freedom as tearing across Liberty City on a motorcycle. An example Achievement / Trophy: “Jump off the tallest building and glide for one minute without touching the ground.” Yesssss.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												Oh Batman: Arkham City, how I love thee.  I don't even know where to begin to explain how fantastic this game is.The story in itself is good, but where the game really shines is in worldbuilding.  The titular Arkham City is probably one of my favorite locations in all of gaming.  The art style and level design just brings the superprison to life, and even the simple conversations between inmates that you can eavesdrop on make the game incredibly immersive.  That's to say nothing of the excellent use of Batman's villian cast.  To go into too much detail would spoil many sidequests, but suffice to say that all are expertly designed, in character, and brought to life by their respective voice actors/actresses (the Riddler being my personal favorite).As for gameplay, it's just as excellent as it was in Aslyum, but has been improved upon like a good sequel should.  On the combat side, you now have the ability to counter multiple enemies at once, all gadgets can be easily incorporated into combat, new special takedowns, and the animations are just as well-detailed from each punch to counter to special takedown that give the combat a finese that few games can match.  And of course, we have the inclusion of multiple playable characters this time as well, from Catwoman to Robin to Nightwing, all of whom have their own unique gadgets and takedowns that shake up the combat.  Stealth as well gets some minor improvements (the ability to quickly end silent takedowns a very welcome addition), and the new gadgets available also offer new ways to neutralize enemies.  Some now take place outdoors as well, giving you even more verticality to the encounters and more tactical approaches and considerations.And of course, we have the challenge mode carried along from Aslyum.  There are now twelve individual maps (split evenly between combat and predator missions), and a new addition: campaign modes, where you tackle three maps back-to-back with qualifers chosen by the player that can either handicap or give you a helping hand.  Unfortunately, this is where I have one big criticism for the game, as the predator missions erroneously followed in the tradition of Aslyum by requiring you to complete specific objectives to beat a level.  On top of most of these objectives being completely arbitrary, and even pointless, then just restrict the player's opportunity to experiment and serve only to make the maps repetitous.  It's a shame they went this route, because the predator encounters in the story mode are fun precisely because they don't have such arbitrary requirements.  Thankfully, the combat challenges aren't structured this way, allowing you to actually experiment with the many combat moves and not be rigidly locked into a routine, and are genuinely fun, meaning you'll want to go back and play them many times over.Tl;dr Batman: Arkham City is easily one of the best games I've played in years, and I could not recommend it highly enough.

												Absolutely fantastic design and gameplay, great addition to the open world and superhero genres.Batman: Arkham City is, as the title suggests, a Batman game with an open Arkham City to explore at your pleasure. Movement feels very fluid as you traverse the monotonously dark city, not saying that's a bad thing. In fact, that's one of the reasons the theme bleeds through so well; the entirety of the game revolves around the gloomy landscape in every one of the missions I've played, main story or side quest. Arkham city is full of lies and crime, and the scenery reflects it.One of the main selling points of the game is the combat. It's simplistic, but still manages to be extremely satisfying and gets quite deep with combos and take downs that you can utilize in different scenarios. The game even incorporates the gliding mechanic into combat, allowing you to swoop down on an enemy and with upgrades, take down multiple at once. Hand to hand feels extremely fluid, almost all counters feel incredibly natural from any angle. Very impressed with just how satisfying combat feels despite only requiring a couple buttons. You can also use your gadgets to disarm and disorient, adding a level of stealth to the game.Speaking of stealth, some missions require you to sneak through passageways and use "detective sense" to figure out  different puzzles. Some gadgets and combat mechanics support this, such as smoke bombs to hide you from enemy vision and silent takedowns to avoid being heard by other enemies. Though it doesn't play a major role in terms of free roaming, it is important in missions and is crucial to master in order to advance to later levels of the game.The last thing I'm going to talk about is completion. In a lot of open world games (i.e. the Assassin's Creed series), there are usually points in the map where you can "activate" in some way to just have some more completion of the game. In Arkham City, these points come in the form of Riddler Trophies, where they require you to solve various puzzles in order to claim them; from everything to simon-says-like memorization to sliding under a grill at the right time. You can spend as much or as little time as you want on these, they're just another thing that you can do that really increases the replyability of this game.Anyway, this game is absolutely amazing so far, I can expect to have a lot of fun with it in the future.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
TL;DR Just buy this game already, it is a masterpiece !This is certainly one of the best games I have played recently, it has everything one could ask for a batman related game !Now, don't get me wrong, honestly I'm not a huge comics fan myself so I wasn't even expecting much out of this game, and  I genuinely had never heard of any of the batman's adventures before so I first played this game literally without knowing anything about him, his allies and his enemies.Well, it turned out to be a great game !The plot is simple yet quite fascinating; you play as the batman, whose real identity is Bruce Wayne, and you're standing against this new "Arkham City", a.k.a a giant prison built in the very heart of Gotham City which is ruled by Dr. Hugo Strange.I'm not going to spoil much of the plot itself, because it is really a good one and I don't want to spoil the fun in exploring it, but know that almost every single batman villain (or at least every villain I know eh) will be present, including the known Joker.The gameplay is pretty good itself, you'll be given many gadgets to solve numerous puzzles with, and you'll be able to fly across the locations of the game with your batman suit. Perhaps the only bad thing gameplay-wise is the combat system, which can be a little easy once you understand how it works, but it is a solid experience regardless.I don't know how much time other people took to finish this game, but it took me 10 hours to finish it at normal difficulty without even touching one single side mission; in fact, I have only just scratched the surface of this game's contents, because, as you continue your adventure throughout the game, you'll unlock challenge maps named which can be played at a latter date, and you'll also unlock a new gamemode upon finishing the game, which will allow you to play the game again but at a very higher difficulty.A lot of years have passed since the official release of this game and yet it still feels fresh, definitely a must have in your steam library.9/10

Posted: April 5, 2016
												I've been trying to think recently of a franchise that told a complete story in two installments; you see trilogies and standalone things all over the place, as well as quadrilogies or whatever they're called, but having 2 installments falls right into the uncanny valley between having one and three (Rule of Three is great and all, but you see it ALL THE F*CKING TIME). Anyway, I think the Arkham games have done that. I don't mean that there are only two installments, as that's demonstrably untrue, but Arkhams Asylum and City form a complete story all by themselves, with no further elaboration required. I like that a lot.Anyway, you want to know if the game's good. Yes, but not quite as good as its predecessor (perhaps my sequel bias again). Overall, this can be attributed to a lack of focus, and seeing as this is a sandbox and Asylum was fairly linear (albeit with a lot of backtracking) that's not at all surprising. However, I'm going to break down the game's elements one by one and discuss them separately.The story suffers from one of the laziest faults in storywriting everywhere: no clear structure. Stuff happens, and then stuff keeps happening, and eventually stuff stops happening as all the various story threads tie themselves up in a nice little bow (mostly). Anyway, it's functional, the setup gives a good sense of escalation from the previous game (which is where I got the 2-installment thing from), and the ending is quite good, so I'll say the story is alright.The combat has been added to without increasing the number of basic elements, which is a really nice thing. There are new animations and context-sensitive takedowns and types of enemies and weapons, so now Batman can do even MORE questionably-nonlethal things to people who probably don't deserve it. However, the way some actual new moves are introduced is a bugbear for me, which I will discuss below.The upgrade system makes no sense, at least in part. Arkham Asylum had the same issue, so I'll talk about both games as one. Batman getting new equipment at predetermined points is fine, because it wouldn't make sense to bring your Line Launcher or Super Duper Upgraded Batclaw wherever you go; you'd call it in or otherwise recieve it as the situation demanded. That's great. I'll even accept upgrades to current equipment, as that still has a veneer of plausibility. But learning new moves over time is just stupid. It's established that the Batman here has been doing this a while, so he's already as good as he's going to get. Why on earth would he, after beating up a certain number of dudes, decide that now he can hold and throw two Batarangs at once, or walk on a tightrope? It's even worse with Arkham City, as firstly the little upgrade bar is called XP, suggesting that Batman had a massive stroke between games and needs to relearn everything; and secondly, the upgrades are presented and unlocked in a grid that reveals more upgrades over time in a pattern that is in no way intuitive. Ugh.Also, there are Catwoman levels, which are fine. Thief Vision irritates both my eyes and the part of my brain devoted to spotting contrivance, but otherwise it works well, and Catwoman is a fun character here.There's a sandbox now, which is fun to get around but I never utilized the side-missions element of. I would appreciate a game in which it's just a normal night and Batman swings around Gotham with all of his stuff, beating up the occasional hoodlum.The boss fights and character animations are better.Overall, Arkham City is a good game, and worth playing. It's not quite as good as Arkham Asylum, in my opinion, but that's no reason to not enjoy it for what it is. Buy it, play through it, and maybe go after all the additional postgame content if you're really having fun with the gameplay.P.S. THEY DID THAT THING WHERE THEY CHANGED AROUND ALL THE HOTKEYS FROM THE FIRST ONE, SO YOU ALWAYS GET CONFUSED AND SELECT THE WRONG THING

												This is great game you should buy it.Pros:-Gameplay is great and fun it only has 2 button combat but it is challenging and i prefer to play the new game + because it gets rid of the icons about enemy actions so you need to keep eye on all the enemies yourself.-Great voice acting-Characters are well done-Good graphics/ art style they still hold up very well even in 2016-playing as Catwoman is fun, it brings fresh variety to game so you can switch character if it gets boring (you can play as both after beating the story)Cons:-Obvious remnant from the console port/ lack of effort for the pc version are the low resolution blurry pre-rendered cutscenes that shouldn't be in a pc game. This also makes the optional Batman skins mostly useless since the cutscenes just show the original outfit because they aren't realtime cutscenes like they should be.-Catwoman's missions should have been longer (They were the most fun missions in the game, at least for me)-No missions replay option. You could replay Catwoman missions in console version but they decided to remove that from the pc version for some strange reason. There is a way to replay missions on pc version but you have to manually make a backup of the savegame file before each mission you wish to replay and then overwrite the nomal save file with the backup file when you wish to replay (Steam save cloud must be disabled)-The DX11 mode is badly optimized and has bad fps drops and stuttering, using DX9 mode works alright.Overall great game, my complaints are very small compared to how much fun the game is.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												The Definitive Batman Gaming Experience.Batman: Arkham City is a masterpiece of a game which displays multiple levels of creativity and care, allowing players to become "The Batman". As the sequel to the criticlly aclaimed Arkham Asylum, Arkham City is rich with improvements from the previous entry while also adding new additions to the series aswell. Arkham City's voice acting is top notch, with many notable cast members; such as the recognizable inclusions of Animated Series Vets: Kevin Conroy portraying the ever "cheerful" Dark Knight, and the marvelous Mark Hamil as the Joker. From the MOMENT you start this game you will not want to put it down as every second within Arkham City is rich with content which will keep you on your toes till the very end. Just about every location within the game is full of nice nods and suprises which makes the long trecs around the city even more enjoyable. The plot of Arkham City is a rollercoaster of events (and even emotions!), that allow even a newcomer to the batman universe to achieve full satisfactory from the contents of the game, while simultaneously satisfying the greatest Batman Fanatics!After you finish the game, the Concept Art gallery, and Character Trophies are some of the best way to understand how much forethought and time went into making this game, which is possibly one of the most pleasurable experiences you'll ever have with a game!(well at least while playing a superhero game).Also, Good news! This is the comeplete edition of the game (Game of the Year), and as with the GOTY edition comes all the wonderful dlc content such as Characters, Challenge Maps, and Batsuits! (But don't play Harley Quinn's Revenge till you finish the main story...spoilers inside).Overall, Batman: Arkham City is a non-stop joyride with twists and turns which will turn you, into the Hero Gotham City deserves.

Posted: May 22, 2016
												   This is a sequel done right. The previous game had masterfull level design and a lot of highs but, a weak story in my opinion and one of the worst ending bosses and scenarios in gaming history. This sequel checks all the boxes to deliver what I believe is still the best Batman game of all time.    Its bigger and more thought out. Not only is the story great but it has twists and turns as is goes on. It's a story within a bigger plot within a BIGGER one. Quite well executed and an improvement from the original. Another positive feet are the side-mission. They are not over saturated and they appear rather organically as you traverse through the large sandbox.Combat has also been improved, giving you more options to proceed with your combos, new moves and animations chage the feel of the game compared to Asylum.    I really have nothing bad to say about the game, perhaps some boring repetetive missions and random ocurrences but I really don't mind. This was a testament that the first game was not merely and experiment. This game, a Batman game influenced many games to come in modern game history. Say what you want, everything is subjective but in my eyes, This is one of the best games ever made.

Posted: October 17, 2013
												Arkham City has that same high level of quality that you'd expect coming from Arkham Asylum with the exception that its flavor is different - trading tighter narrative of the original for an open world approach designed to test your inner collector with all the side missions and, well, collectibles. It does suffer from a minor content overload that persists throughout the entire game, but you'll never hear me complaining about more of the good stuff when its actually good and worth digesting. Story department does manage to deliver a few shockers, although it's somewhat arguable there are perhaps too many recognizable Batman characters all crammed into a single game which leads to a loss of focus. I won't even pretend to have completed more than half of what the game has to offer with all the challenges and trials OUTSIDE of the main campaign, but it deserves a seal of approval regardless.

Posted: June 8, 2015
												TLDR – This follow up to the amazing Batman Arkham Asylum brings more villains, more bat tools, and a bigger playground to stomp around in. If you liked Arkham Asylum, you’ll like Arkham City. Just make sure you play the first game first so you know what’s going on with your old pal the Joker.Batman Arkham City is bigger and better than its predecessor not only because of the larger “open world” city, but also with improvements to Batman’s combat skills and equipment. One of the biggest differences is the ability to fly around using the grapnel boost upgrade, which you unlock by completing some optional training missions. Instead of running around most of the time like in Arkham Asylum, you’ll spend much more time on rooftops and soaring through the night like a majestic bat pretending to be a majestic eagle.*Spoilers for the first Arkham game*The story of Arkham City picks up maybe a year after Batman put down the Joker’s uprising in Arkham Asylum. If you recall, Joker’s attempt to transform himself into a titan monster left him pretty messed up after he took an explosive punch in the face from Batman. Now, Joker has been locked in Arkham City, which is a section right in the middle of Gotham City that’s been sealed off and turned into a survival of the fittest no man’s land, where the scum of Gotham are dumped to keep them away from the good citizens. What this means is that in the middle of Gotham City is a walled off area several miles in diameter filled with super criminals and their gangs battling each other for supremacy. It’s an idea so bad that even billionaire playboy Bruce Wayne speaks out about it, and is promptly captured and thrown in by Arkham City’s director Hugo Strange (and his mysterious benefactor).Pros:+Great story including even more Batman super villains that you didn’t see in the first game. Mister Freeze, Penguin, Dead shot, Two-Face, and many others show up to ruin Batman’s day. Most baddies from the first game returns as well so it’s a good thing Batman has more tools and combos to use. Plus, there are a few sections where you can play as Batman’s pseudo friend Catwoman. Joker isn’t even your main enemy, though he probably represents the greatest immediate threat.+The game’s combat seems to flow better, though once again, it’s all about using the “counter” where you can instantly block or dodge most enemies’ attacks, and give them a boot to the face for their troubles. Like in the Assassin’s Creed games, if your timing is good, the game makes you feel like a badass close combat expert.+Steam upgraded everyone’s version of the game to the Game of the Year edition, so you have extra character skins, challenge maps, and the Harley Quinn’s Revenge DLC, which is a nice mini campaign where you play as Robin. Cons:-Just like Arkham Asylum, the only (minor) gripe I have is how much collectible hunting there is. Once again, The Riddler has stashed puzzles and items all over the place and you need to find them if you want to have 100% game completion. In the game’s main menu, there’s a % progress number to give you a hint how far along you are in the game, but it’s deceptive because the game’s campaign story only accounts for about 33%. I don’t mind gathering collectibles if they can be easily found during regular playthrough, but after the story’s over I don’t like revisiting every area in the game to collect items that are no longer useful. I’m probably in the minority here though.Overall, the game is an A+ 9.5/10. If you want to lose yourself in Batman lore brought to you via a great story and gameplay, do yourself a favor and play Batman Arkham City.

Posted: September 18, 2015
												Fantastic. I've just started on 1% of the game but I am already impressed. I'll add more as I keep on playing. At $5 on sale, with all the DLC, I think it's worth it. Will add more when I complete the game.Finished the main campaign, other than a few cons, most impressed with the details.PROS1. Graphics***So much detail. I must say that the artist really put in a lot of effort to design a dark Industrial-age like Arkham City. Kudos to the team. I felt like I was playing the comic.a. Arkham City (Especially the details and the inner design. Who's your artist?)b. Costume design (Even the thugs, but not Robin's)c. Villians (I liked Harley Quinn the most)2. CombatSo smooth, so beautiful. Even though I'm just tapping the Left and Right Mouse buttons, the combat moves so smoothly. You can even cause enemies to interact with the environment E.g. By smashing their faces into the walls3. Detective ModeReally fun pretending to be a real detective. Of course, I understand that this isn't a real CSI but I do appreciate simple realism. E.g. How they calculate the bullets trajectory from Joker's sniper rifle. The X-Ray vision and highlighting of important objects is vital as well.4. CharactersLove Harley Quinn. So wild, so cute, so attractive. Can't wait to see the rest. This is most surprising as I had already watched some parts of the game on Youtube. It's so fun. Even after the main campaign finishes, you get to find Riddler, Killer Croc, Bane, Posion Ivy and so on.5. Arkham CityIt gives you a really good feeling seeing the walls surround the giant prison which is Arkham City. The way it's built up just ties into the story so well.6. GadgetsI love them. I especially love the ingenious use of combat + utility. E.g. Using the Batarang for combat and hitting buttons. Using the Batclaw to disarm and open seals. Using the electric charge gun to stun bosses and turn on motors. It really makes the weapons so much more useful. Compared to other games, where a weapon is just a weapon and a tool is just a tool, this really provide another avenue for clever gameplay.7. ReplayabilityI never thought that I would enjoy going back to the same place twice but Rocksteady Studios really does make the game fun. I especially liked the old GCPD map where you can first go through Penguin's goons and later Mr Freeze's boss fight.8. AIa. Heartbeat monitor. I loved it. This is so much more realistic than other stealth games, where you knock someone out and no one notices he's gone for hours.b. Radio Communications. Great to get game information and to search for clues.9. Riddler's PuzzlesI appreciate the simple, yet thoughtful puzzles. It forces you to think just that little bit more without creating a full blown mental exam.10. Multi-charactersCatwoman was fun. Using the whip was a totally new way of playing. Robin was too similar to Batman to warrant anything interesting.11. StorySo interesting. Penguin's museum collection, the underground Gotham City, the Lazarus project, Hugo Strange etc... I still don't get why Batman doesn't kill though... It is extremely righteous but it takes a little of the suspension of disbelief away.... Practically, it seems totally impossible...CONS1. Button ControlsThe Left Control + Space command is extremely difficult to do and is intutitive. It's used for dropping off the edge but it's quite silly.2. Glide KickYou would think that dropping from a height + smashing a face into the ground would instantly KO an enemy, yet this game seems to create some peculiar situations where you have to link another KO move.3. Riddler Hostage RescueToo many puzzles to solve just to get to the end. 400/600 Riddler trophies plus challanges just to rescue the hostage. I couldn't take it at a 160. When I realised the next rescue required 320 trophies. That was too much and gave up.4. Balloons, Harley Heads, Joker Teeth, Penguin modelsReally silly to have to so many things to shoot that have no value, only a challenge completed. You need to complete them just to do Riddler's hostage quest.5. Dead end MapsSome maps just become empty voids after use. E.g. The Lazarus Pit. Once you finish with it, there's only a Riddler trophy to get. This guy is Batman, he comes from the direction you least expect. It is most silly to limit Batman to doors and watch him walk into an ambush.6. Thug BodiesIf you watch the Batman shows, the thugs usually disappear quietly into the darkness. There is no unconscious body. Batman would tie them up and leave them hanging and gagged. The thugs leaving their buddy hanging or unconscious bodies unable to wake up are super silly.SUGGESTIONS1. Multiple Entrances/ExitsThis is for CON 5. Once you finish with a location, there should be another entrance or instant travel to that area as a reward. It's necessary for maps that can't use the grapnel hook. E.g. Subway.2. Gang/Turf Wars3 major gangs, Joker, Two-Face and Penguin plus TYGER. I was hoping that there would be zones where there were firefights between the gangs. E.g. Joker's snipers shooting at Penguin's men who are hiding behind cover.3. Tying Up ThugsBatman would probably have an option of tagging, hanging and gagging the thugs. It would be more true to the Batman saga. He works on Stealth Mode not fisticuffs.

By smashing their faces into the walls3. Detective ModeReally fun pretending to be a real detective. Of course, I understand that this isn't a real CSI but I do appreciate simple realism. E.g. How they calculate the bullets trajectory from Joker's sniper rifle. The X-Ray vision and highlighting of important objects is vital as well.4. CharactersLove Harley Quinn. So wild, so cute, so attractive. Can't wait to see the rest. This is most surprising as I had already watched some parts of the game on Youtube. It's so fun. Even after the main campaign finishes, you get to find Riddler, Killer Croc, Bane, Posion Ivy and so on.5. Arkham CityIt gives you a really good feeling seeing the walls surround the giant prison which is Arkham City. The way it's built up just ties into the story so well.6. GadgetsI love them. I especially love the ingenious use of combat + utility. E.g. Using the Batarang for combat and hitting buttons. Using the Batclaw to disarm and open seals. Using the electric charge gun to stun bosses and turn on motors. It really makes the weapons so much more useful. Compared to other games, where a weapon is just a weapon and a tool is just a tool, this really provide another avenue for clever gameplay.7. ReplayabilityI never thought that I would enjoy going back to the same place twice but Rocksteady Studios really does make the game fun. I especially liked the old GCPD map where you can first go through Penguin's goons and later Mr Freeze's boss fight.8. AIa. Heartbeat monitor. I loved it. This is so much more realistic than other stealth games, where you knock someone out and no one notices he's gone for hours.b. Radio Communications. Great to get game information and to search for clues.9. Riddler's PuzzlesI appreciate the simple, yet thoughtful puzzles. It forces you to think just that little bit more without creating a full blown mental exam.10. Multi-charactersCatwoman was fun. Using the whip was a totally new way of playing. Robin was too similar to Batman to warrant anything interesting.11. StorySo interesting. Penguin's museum collection, the underground Gotham City, the Lazarus project, Hugo Strange etc... I still don't get why Batman doesn't kill though... It is extremely righteous but it takes a little of the suspension of disbelief away.... Practically, it seems totally impossible...CONS1. Button ControlsThe Left Control + Space command is extremely difficult to do and is intutitive. It's used for dropping off the edge but it's quite silly.2. Glide KickYou would think that dropping from a height + smashing a face into the ground would instantly KO an enemy, yet this game seems to create some peculiar situations where you have to link another KO move.3. Riddler Hostage RescueToo many puzzles to solve just to get to the end. 400/600 Riddler trophies plus challanges just to rescue the hostage. I couldn't take it at a 160. When I realised the next rescue required 320 trophies. That was too much and gave up.4. Balloons, Harley Heads, Joker Teeth, Penguin modelsReally silly to have to so many things to shoot that have no value, only a challenge completed. You need to complete them just to do Riddler's hostage quest.5. Dead end MapsSome maps just become empty voids after use. E.g. The Lazarus Pit. Once you finish with it, there's only a Riddler trophy to get. This guy is Batman, he comes from the direction you least expect. It is most silly to limit Batman to doors and watch him walk into an ambush.6. Thug BodiesIf you watch the Batman shows, the thugs usually disappear quietly into the darkness. There is no unconscious body. Batman would tie them up and leave them hanging and gagged. The thugs leaving their buddy hanging or unconscious bodies unable to wake up are super silly.SUGGESTIONS1. Multiple Entrances/ExitsThis is for CON 5. Once you finish with a location, there should be another entrance or instant travel to that area as a reward. It's necessary for maps that can't use the grapnel hook. E.g. Subway.2. Gang/Turf Wars3 major gangs, Joker, Two-Face and Penguin plus TYGER. I was hoping that there would be zones where there were firefights between the gangs. E.g. Joker's snipers shooting at Penguin's men who are hiding behind cover.3. Tying Up ThugsBatman would probably have an option of tagging, hanging and gagging the thugs. It would be more true to the Batman saga. He works on Stealth Mode not fisticuffs.

												I love this installment of Batman, very good story and intresting world to explorer. Really nice side missions along with the main story. It took me more then 25 hours gameplay to complete this game.. Arkham City is stuffed to the edge of with content and replay value (in addition to the gigantic campaign there's an expanded Challenge Mode and New Game Plus), is incredible amounts of fun, that will allow you more then 25 hours gameplay. Arkham City is by far a  better game in delivering an immaculately presented, rich, compelling play experience and very intresting and emotionfilled story while it is true to the Batman franchise and giving players imense feel of how it is being Batman. Enjoyed every bit of this excellent game. Sometimes the boss fights got on my nerve, but thanks to the hints after dying, I got the hang of how to kill some of the bosses. You would love the gripping fighting system, lots of diversity  as you have loads of choices to make and a great atmosphere since the world is a "open world", this is the best superhero according to me. I just loved it!

Posted: October 4, 2016
												The most highly-marketed feature of Batman: Arkham City is the replacement of the small, confined corridors of the previous game with an open-world setting. Ironically, this feature is also the worst aspect of the game, and one of the primary reasons that the sequel doesn't quite live up to Rocksteady Studios' previous effort.One year after the events of Arkham Asylum, Bruce Wayne is abducted and imprisoned within Arkham City, a controversial prison within a walled-off section of Gotham overseen by private security forces led by a mysterious villain named Hugo Strange, who makes it clear up-front that he knows Batman's true identity. It's almost comical how quickly things escalate, with Bruce Wayne being captured by the Penguin literally at the front gate of Arkham City. Weirdly enough, just about none of the game has anything to do with the initial problem of Batman's identity being revealed, and Hugo Strange himself only really comes into villainhood in the game's final act, with the majority of the game's runtime dedicated to the Joker - an infinitely more interesting villain that any of Batman's other enemies, most of whom are regulated to minor, almost tangential missions early in the game. In fact, a lot of the plot is actually just tangents, with the purpose of leading the player on a merry tour of the big, gloomy world that's been constructed. It's lacking in focus for the most part, with one very specific MacGuffin loosely tying everything together. For sure, the villains are still just as good as they were in Arkham Asylum, and there are certainly more of them, but most of them are just minor acknowledgements of actual character, instead just displaying the characteristics for which they are most well-known. To make things even more dire on the story front, the game of the year edition incorporates the normally separate Catwoman DLC into the main story, spreading the missions throughout the game's length, serving only to completely break the flow of both the game and the DLC.While the story's a bit of a mess this time around, the gameplay is pretty spot-on. Most of the new stuff that's been introduced is simple and easy to use, and in general the combat just flows a lot better, making for an even more delightful experience in kicking impoverished homeless people in the teeth. Even better, efforts have actually been made to stop Batman from being incredibly overpowered in stealth segments, with new gear that scrambles x-ray vision and sees long distances, even in the dark. The combat is still a lot more fun - it's fast and surprisingly tactical considering the entire premise is punching large quantities of men. The introductions of new enemy types has done a lot to keep it all fresh and challenging, especially in massive brawls involving weapons and the classic giant mutants from the original game. In short, while Arkham City is quite a bit worse on the story front, and it lacks the tight focus and thick atmosphere that shrouded Arkham Asylum, though it makes up some lost ground with myriad gameplay and control improvements, coming together as a finished product that's overall worse than it's predecessor, but still a lot of fun.My review of Batman: Arkham Asylum
